example[0]: My parents divorced when I was six, and I hardly knew my father.
example[1]: The children were so excited they could hardly speak.
example[3]: Hardly anyone (=almost no one) writes to me these days.
example[5]: There was hardly any (=very little) traffic.
example[6]: She lives in Spain, so we hardly ever (=almost never) see her.
example[7]: Hardly a month goes by without another factory closing down.
note[0]: hardly a day/week/month etc goes by without/when
definition[1]: used to mean ‘not’, when you are suggesting that the person you are speaking to will agree with you
example[8]: It’s hardly surprising that she won’t answer his calls after the way he’s treated her.
example[9]: You can hardly blame Tom for not waiting.
example[10]: My boss could hardly be described as handsome.
example[11]: This is hardly the place to discuss the matter.
definition[2]: used to say that something has only just happened
example[12]: The building work has hardly begun.
example[13]: She had hardly sat down when the phone rang.
explanation[0]: Hardly usually comes before a main verb
explanation[1]: Hardly comes after the first auxiliary verb
example[15]: I can hardly believe you said that
example[16]: We could hardly have known what was going to happen next
bad_example[0]: I hardly can believe you said that
explanation[2]: Hardly usually comes after the verb ‘be’ when it is used in simple tenses such as ‘is’ or ‘was’
explanation[3]: In writing, you can use hardly at the beginning of a sentence before an auxiliary to say that one thing happens very soon after another thing
example[18]: Hardly had the rain stopped, when the sun came out
explanation[5]: Hardly is not the adverb of hard The adverb of hard  is hard
